children.subject: However many you need to feel you have fully answered the question in a way that depicts you.
<md>How many words should I write for each prompt? </md>
Expect decisions before the semester starts.
You must take the class for a unit, sorry department rules
I remember that if you AI in the summer you can defer your units to Fall or even further to avoid paying summer tuition. Can one likewise defer their units to future semesters to stay under 130 unit?
Similar situation here with the unit ceiling. Clarification please.
You cannot defer units during the regular semester

<md>I was wondering how strict the 1 unit requirement is? I'm in a pretty tough situation with class units since I am a transfer student and am about to hit the unit ceiling, but would really love to help students in 61b (was my favorite lower div cs course). </md>

Yes, you will only be responsible to complete assignments that you will be helping students with (no need to do the projects). I will also provide videos to interns to help you get those done efficiently
When it says "Regularly submit assignments to the autograder", does it mean that interns are expected to finish only the labs assigned to students?
Have the application decisions been finalized/sent out yet?
<md>Can we still apply for interning? I was out of the country with no internet connection so I did not meet the deadline.</md>

history.content:
Would you like to pass some of your computer science knowledge down to others? Would you like to better your grip on fundamental CS material? Would you like to take your first steps toward joining the CS 61B course staff? If logical-or-ing your answers to the above questions == true, please consider becoming an Academic Intern for CS61B Spring 2021!

As an intern you will help facilitate labs by helping students with their assignments and conceptual understanding of the class.

All interns will be expected to:

  • Attend a pre-semester talk about the program / instructing students.
  • Have one half hour mid-semester meeting with your TA and their other interns.

  • Regularly submit assignments to the autograder (these are the same assignments students will be completing).

  • Fill out the mid-semester survey.

  • Attend 80% of your required labs. There may be some make up opportunities available. Each lab will be two hours long.

This internship is designed to take roughly 3 hours of your time per week. Labs must be attended synchronously but other duties can be completed asychronously. The lab will be made available to you in advance and will be accompanied by a walkthrough video (ft. me) which will be much more revealing of the solution than resources allotted to the students. You are required to complete it and submit labs to Gradescope in preparation for your lab.

For your time and effort as an Intern, you will be awarded 1 unit of PNP credit for the Spring 2021 semester. Completing all of the above bullet points will get you a P. You cannot become an intern without taking the class for a unit.

The Application is Available Here. It is due Tuesday, January 12th Thursday, January 14th at 11:59pm PDT. Expect decisions before the semester starts.

Here are some common questions I always get about applying to be an intern:

Do I need to have gotten an A in 61B to apply?

No, the application process is grade blind. You are selected based off your answers to the application questions. Potential applicants often express to me that they do not feel "qualified" for the position and they always are. This is as much as opertunity for you to learn the material a second time as it is to get teaching experience.

I am undecided if I want to apply, should I?

If you are considering becoming an intern but unsure if you can commit to it, I would recommend filling the application out anyways.

What times are available for labs?

This will not be decided until closer towards the semester. Labs are normally W-F. Take a look at last semester's website to get an idea what the shedule might look like.

Please comment below with any further questions or email me at alexschedel@berkeley.edu if you have any more personal questions.
